trans-unit.source: Creating web apps with Flask in Azure
trans-unit.target: Creating web apps with Flask in Azure

trans-unit.source: A tutorial that introduces you to running a Python web app on Azure.
trans-unit.target: A tutorial that introduces you to running a Python web app on Azure.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial describes how to get started running Python in <linkText>Azure App Service Web Apps</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial describes how to get started running Python in <linkText>Azure App Service Web Apps</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Web Apps provides limited free hosting and rapid deployment, and you can use Python!
trans-unit.target: Web Apps provides limited free hosting and rapid deployment, and you can use Python!

trans-unit.source: As your app grows, you can switch to paid hosting, and you can also integrate with all of the other Azure services.
trans-unit.target: As your app grows, you can switch to paid hosting, and you can also integrate with all of the other Azure services.

trans-unit.source: You will create an application using the Flask web framework (see alternate versions of this tutorial for <linkText>Django</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Bottle</linkText><title></title>).
trans-unit.target: You will create an application using the Flask web framework (see alternate versions of this tutorial for <linkText>Django</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Bottle</linkText><title></title>).

trans-unit.source: You will create the website from the Azure gallery, set up Git deployment, and clone the repository locally.
trans-unit.target: You will create the website from the Azure gallery, set up Git deployment, and clone the repository locally.

trans-unit.source: Then you will run the application locally, make changes, commit and push them to Azure.
trans-unit.target: Then you will run the application locally, make changes, commit and push them to Azure.

trans-unit.source: The tutorial shows how to do this from Windows or Mac/Linux.
trans-unit.target: The tutorial shows how to do this from Windows or Mac/Linux.

trans-unit.source: If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to <linkText>Try App Service</linkText><title></title>, where you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service.
trans-unit.target: If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to <linkText>Try App Service</linkText><title></title>, where you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service.

trans-unit.source: No credit cards required; no commitments.
trans-unit.target: No credit cards required; no commitments.

trans-unit.source: Windows, Mac or Linux
trans-unit.target: Windows, Mac or Linux

trans-unit.source: Python 2.7 or 3.4
trans-unit.target: Python 2.7 or 3.4

trans-unit.source: setuptools, pip, virtualenv (Python 2.7 only)
trans-unit.target: setuptools, pip, virtualenv (Python 2.7 only)

trans-unit.source: Git
trans-unit.target: Git

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Python Tools for Visual Studio</linkText><title></title> (PTVS) - Note: this is optional
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Python Tools for Visual Studio</linkText><title></title> (PTVS) - Note: this is optional

trans-unit.source: Note: TFS publishing is currently not supported for Python projects.
trans-unit.target: Note: TFS publishing is currently not supported for Python projects.

trans-unit.source: If you don't already have Python 2.7 or 3.4 installed (32-bit), we recommend installing [Azure SDK for Python 2.7] or [Azure SDK for Python 3.4] using Web Platform Installer.
trans-unit.target: If you don't already have Python 2.7 or 3.4 installed (32-bit), we recommend installing [Azure SDK for Python 2.7] or [Azure SDK for Python 3.4] using Web Platform Installer.

trans-unit.source: This installs the 32-bit version of Python, setuptools, pip, virtualenv, etc (32-bit Python is what's installed on the Azure host machines).
trans-unit.target: This installs the 32-bit version of Python, setuptools, pip, virtualenv, etc (32-bit Python is what's installed on the Azure host machines).

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, you can get Python from [python.org].
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, you can get Python from [python.org].

trans-unit.source: For Git, we recommend [Git for Windows] or [GitHub for Windows].
trans-unit.target: For Git, we recommend [Git for Windows] or [GitHub for Windows].

trans-unit.source: If you use Visual Studio, you can use the integrated Git support.
trans-unit.target: If you use Visual Studio, you can use the integrated Git support.

trans-unit.source: We also recommend installing [Python Tools 2.2 for Visual Studio].
trans-unit.target: We also recommend installing [Python Tools 2.2 for Visual Studio].

trans-unit.source: This is optional, but if you have [Visual Studio], including the free Visual Studio Community 2013 or Visual Studio Express 2013 for Web, then this will give you a great Python IDE.
trans-unit.target: This is optional, but if you have [Visual Studio], including the free Visual Studio Community 2013 or Visual Studio Express 2013 for Web, then this will give you a great Python IDE.

trans-unit.source: You should have Python and Git already installed, but make sure you have either Python 2.7 or 3.4.
trans-unit.target: You should have Python and Git already installed, but make sure you have either Python 2.7 or 3.4.

trans-unit.source: The first step in creating your app is to create the web app via the <linkText>Azure Portal</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The first step in creating your app is to create the web app via the <linkText>Azure Portal</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Log into the Azure Portal and click the NEW button in the bottom left corner.
trans-unit.target: Log into the Azure Portal and click the NEW button in the bottom left corner.

trans-unit.source: Click Web + Mobile > Azure Marketplace > Web Apps.
trans-unit.target: Click Web + Mobile > Azure Marketplace > Web Apps.

trans-unit.source: In the search box, type "python".
trans-unit.target: In the search box, type "python".

trans-unit.source: In the search results, select Flask, then click Create.
trans-unit.target: In the search results, select Flask, then click Create.

trans-unit.source: Configure the new Flask app, such as creating a new App Service plan and a new resource group for it.
trans-unit.target: Configure the new Flask app, such as creating a new App Service plan and a new resource group for it.

trans-unit.source: Then, click Create.
trans-unit.target: Then, click Create.

trans-unit.source: Configure Git publishing for your newly created web app by following the instructions at <linkText>Continuous deployment using GIT in Azure App Service</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Configure Git publishing for your newly created web app by following the instructions at <linkText>Continuous deployment using GIT in Azure App Service</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Here's an overview of the files you'll find in the initial Git repository, which we'll clone in the next section.
trans-unit.target: Here's an overview of the files you'll find in the initial Git repository, which we'll clone in the next section.

trans-unit.source: Main sources for the application.
trans-unit.target: Main sources for the application.

trans-unit.source: Consists of 3 pages (index, about, contact) with a master layout.
trans-unit.target: Consists of 3 pages (index, about, contact) with a master layout.

trans-unit.source: Static content and scripts include bootstrap, jquery, modernizr and respond.
trans-unit.target: Static content and scripts include bootstrap, jquery, modernizr and respond.

trans-unit.source: Local development server support.
trans-unit.target: Local development server support.

trans-unit.source: Use this to run the application locally.
trans-unit.target: Use this to run the application locally.

trans-unit.source: Project files for use with [Python Tools for Visual Studio].
trans-unit.target: Project files for use with [Python Tools for Visual Studio].

trans-unit.source: IIS proxy for virtual environments and PTVS remote debugging support.
trans-unit.target: IIS proxy for virtual environments and PTVS remote debugging support.

trans-unit.source: External packages needed by this application.
trans-unit.target: External packages needed by this application.

trans-unit.source: The deployment script will pip install the packages listed in this file.
trans-unit.target: The deployment script will pip install the packages listed in this file.

trans-unit.source: IIS configuration files.
trans-unit.target: IIS configuration files.

trans-unit.source: The deployment script will use the appropriate web.x.y.config and copy it as web.config.
trans-unit.target: The deployment script will use the appropriate web.x.y.config and copy it as web.config.

trans-unit.source: Some files exist on the server but are not added to the git repository.
trans-unit.target: Some files exist on the server but are not added to the git repository.

trans-unit.source: These are created by the deployment script.
trans-unit.target: These are created by the deployment script.

trans-unit.source: IIS configuration file.
trans-unit.target: IIS configuration file.

trans-unit.source: Created from web.x.y.config on every deployment.
trans-unit.target: Created from web.x.y.config on every deployment.

trans-unit.source: Python virtual environment.
trans-unit.target: Python virtual environment.

trans-unit.source: Created during deployment if a compatible virtual environment doesn't already exist on the app.
trans-unit.target: Created during deployment if a compatible virtual environment doesn't already exist on the app.

trans-unit.source: Packages listed in requirements.txt are pip installed, but pip will skip installation if the packages are already installed.
trans-unit.target: Packages listed in requirements.txt are pip installed, but pip will skip installation if the packages are already installed.

trans-unit.source: The next 3 sections describe how to proceed with the web app development under 3 different environments:
trans-unit.target: The next 3 sections describe how to proceed with the web app development under 3 different environments:

trans-unit.source: Windows, with Python Tools for Visual Studio
trans-unit.target: Windows, with Python Tools for Visual Studio

trans-unit.source: Windows, with command line
trans-unit.target: Windows, with command line

trans-unit.source: Mac/Linux, with command line
trans-unit.target: Mac/Linux, with command line

trans-unit.source: First, clone the repository using the URL provided on the Azure Portal.
trans-unit.target: First, clone the repository using the URL provided on the Azure Portal.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Continuous deployment using GIT in Azure App Service</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Continuous deployment using GIT in Azure App Service</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Open the solution file (.sln) that is included in the root of the repository.
trans-unit.target: Open the solution file (.sln) that is included in the root of the repository.

trans-unit.source: Now we'll create a virtual environment for local development.
trans-unit.target: Now we'll create a virtual environment for local development.

trans-unit.source: Right-click on Python Environments select Add Virtual Environment....
trans-unit.target: Right-click on Python Environments select Add Virtual Environment....

trans-unit.source: Make sure the name of the environment is env.
trans-unit.target: Make sure the name of the environment is env.

trans-unit.source: Select the base interpreter.
trans-unit.target: Select the base interpreter.

trans-unit.source: Make sure to use the same version of Python that is selected for your web app (in runtime.txt or the Application Settings blade of your web app in the Azure Portal).
trans-unit.target: Make sure to use the same version of Python that is selected for your web app (in runtime.txt or the Application Settings blade of your web app in the Azure Portal).

trans-unit.source: Make sure the option to download and install packages is checked.
trans-unit.target: Make sure the option to download and install packages is checked.

trans-unit.source: Click Create.
trans-unit.target: Click Create.

trans-unit.source: This will create the virtual environment, and install dependencies listed in requirements.txt.
trans-unit.target: This will create the virtual environment, and install dependencies listed in requirements.txt.

trans-unit.source: Press F5 to start debugging, and your web browser will open automatically to the page running locally.
trans-unit.target: Press F5 to start debugging, and your web browser will open automatically to the page running locally.

trans-unit.source: You can set breakpoints in the sources, use the watch windows, etc. See the [Python Tools for Visual Studio Documentation] for more information on the various features.
trans-unit.target: You can set breakpoints in the sources, use the watch windows, etc. See the [Python Tools for Visual Studio Documentation] for more information on the various features.

trans-unit.source: Now you can experiment by making changes to the application sources and/or templates.
trans-unit.target: Now you can experiment by making changes to the application sources and/or templates.

trans-unit.source: After you've tested your changes, commit them to the Git repository:
trans-unit.target: After you've tested your changes, commit them to the Git repository:

trans-unit.source: Your application may have dependencies beyond Python and Flask.
trans-unit.target: Your application may have dependencies beyond Python and Flask.

trans-unit.source: You can install additional packages using pip.
trans-unit.target: You can install additional packages using pip.

trans-unit.source: To install a package, right-click on the virtual environment and select Install Python Package.
trans-unit.target: To install a package, right-click on the virtual environment and select Install Python Package.

trans-unit.source: For example, to install the Azure SDK for Python, which gives you access to Azure storage, service bus and other Azure services, enter azure:
trans-unit.target: For example, to install the Azure SDK for Python, which gives you access to Azure storage, service bus and other Azure services, enter azure:

trans-unit.source: Right-click on the virtual environment and select Generate requirements.txt to update requirements.txt.
trans-unit.target: Right-click on the virtual environment and select Generate requirements.txt to update requirements.txt.

trans-unit.source: Then, commit the changes to requirements.txt to the Git repository.
trans-unit.target: Then, commit the changes to requirements.txt to the Git repository.

trans-unit.source: To trigger a deployment, click on Sync or Push.
trans-unit.target: To trigger a deployment, click on Sync or Push.

trans-unit.source: Sync does both a push and a pull.
trans-unit.target: Sync does both a push and a pull.

trans-unit.source: The first deployment will take some time, as it will create a virtual environment, install packages, etc.
trans-unit.target: The first deployment will take some time, as it will create a virtual environment, install packages, etc.

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio doesn't show the progress of the deployment.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio doesn't show the progress of the deployment.

trans-unit.source: If you'd like to review the output, see the section on <linkText>Troubleshooting - Deployment</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If you'd like to review the output, see the section on <linkText>Troubleshooting - Deployment</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Browse to the Azure URL to view your changes.
trans-unit.target: Browse to the Azure URL to view your changes.

trans-unit.source: First, clone the repository using the URL provided on the Azure Portal, and add the Azure repository as a remote.
trans-unit.target: First, clone the repository using the URL provided on the Azure Portal, and add the Azure repository as a remote.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Continuous deployment using GIT in Azure App Service</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Continuous deployment using GIT in Azure App Service</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: We'll create a new virtual environment for development purposes (do not add it to the repository).
trans-unit.target: We'll create a new virtual environment for development purposes (do not add it to the repository).

trans-unit.source: Virtual environments in Python are not relocatable, so every developer working on the application will create their own locally.
trans-unit.target: Virtual environments in Python are not relocatable, so every developer working on the application will create their own locally.

trans-unit.source: Make sure to use the same version of Python that is selected for your web app (in runtime.txt or the Application Settings blade of your web app in the Azure Portal).
trans-unit.target: Make sure to use the same version of Python that is selected for your web app (in runtime.txt or the Application Settings blade of your web app in the Azure Portal).

trans-unit.target: Install any external packages required by your application.

trans-unit.target: You can use the requirements.txt file at the root of the repository to install the packages in your virtual environment:

trans-unit.target: You can install additional packages using pip.
